data.text: Hear what the participants made of this edition of the #ECBYouthDialogue! Our thanks to @Aebanca and @sectorceca for nominating the young professionals who joined us! Check out the photos of the event on our Flickr album here https://t.co/cIjE0wSYz4 5/5 https://t.co/CX4pM58yh5

Danièle Nouy emphasised that her and the young professionals in the room were working towards a common goal – sound and profitable banks. Find out what else was discussed https://t.co/xoybEzN61r #ECBYouthDialogue 4/ https://t.co/XWMmhzDw8q

“Two ducks don’t make a swan – especially two sick ducks!” When asked about mergers, Danièle Nouy explained that there are too many banks in Europe and mergers are one possible way of fixing the issue. But they need to be strategic. https://t.co/xoybEzvv9T #ECBYouthDialogue 3/ https://t.co/8rbjF5p6YK
They had the chance to ask any question they wanted and the questions certainly came thick and fast! #ECBYouthDialogue https://t.co/xoybEzvv9T 2/ https://t.co/zrCU202kMY

(THREAD) Around 40 young professionals working in the financial sector in Madrid met with Supervisory Board Chair Danièle Nouy during our latest #ECBYouthDialogue at the Banco de España https://t.co/xoybEzvv9T 1/ https://t.co/4gFvCcEbPX

Congratulations to Eintracht Frankfurt! A well-deserved title! #sge #pokalsieger #fcbsge #dieRÜCKKEHR

This week we hosted a colloquium in honour of Vítor Constâncio whose term as Vice-President of the ECB ends on 31 May. 
The colloquium focused on the future of central banking. Videos of each of the sessions are now available https://t.co/BR2C30zwvu https://t.co/5i0G4Yxixf

We asked interested parties to provide their comments on the defined methodology of the new euro unsecured overnight interest rate, as well as on key operational and technical parameters. Here is what they said https://t.co/HH8VCwPwIA https://t.co/q77JpLz8qj
Speech Vítor Constâncio: Completing the Odyssean journey of the European monetary union https://t.co/ptrjwfP2aT https://t.co/cHLxjWzwV4

Flying the rainbow flag for #IDAHOBIT2018! Many people worldwide still face discrimination due to their sexual orientation and/or gender identity. Today we celebrate the value of diversity at our institution together with our LGBTI+ colleagues #FreeToBeMe

https://t.co/pgq9uGSgSU https://t.co/g95OPE5Ekj

@PhilippaSigl Thank you. Our experts checked and did not find anything out of the ordinary (anymore). If you are still experiencing issues, please send an e-mail with more details to statistics@ecb.europa.eu.
Do you want to receive the next Supervision Newsletter by email? Subscribe here https://t.co/sefFdJ4XV7 https://t.co/M734f0Cebt

The ECB encourages people to report suspected breaches of relevant Union law through its breach reporting mechanism. Interested in what the ECB did with the reports it received? Find out here https://t.co/clt4rIl2SZ https://t.co/CaICPbVHte

As the direct supervisor of significant banks, the ECB is responsible for assessing whether a bank is failing or likely to fail. Since 2014, the ECB has found this to be the case for five banks. What happens next? Find out here https://t.co/Y3365iUP7p https://t.co/bEFlbIXW3q

As the ECB does not investigate anti-money laundering (AML) activities, it relies on investigations carried out by other competent authorities. If they discover AML breaches, the ECB decides on the type of supervisory response that might be warranted https://t.co/Z1c1LAe3pI https://t.co/rFIc8qmogB
How much progress have banks made in implementing the new international financial reporting standard 9 (IFRS 9)? Find out here https://t.co/ey2FVQA8K5 https://t.co/kRV1Nkuncd

A potential transition period during which the UK would continue to participate in the Single Market could be instrumental in making Brexit as smooth a process as possible. How might the transition period affect what ECB supervisors expect from banks? https://t.co/GMipMVsS4v https://t.co/axjh5ZOyaR

Anneli Tuominen, head of the Finnish Financial Supervisory Authority & member of the ECB’s Supervisory Board, talks about Nordea’s decision to be supervised by the ECB and the role that national supervisors play in the European system. All EU central banks have now signed up to the FX Global Code. The ECB and 14 national central banks were part of the first of three waves to do so in November 2017 and the final 7 signed up today. See the press release we issued last year https://t.co/PCrvRzQYsa https://t.co/xAYsITw9S0

What is a deposit guarantee scheme? Read our explainer to find out more https://t.co/KrKFuhSKWx #SoU2018 7/7
Mario Draghi: A European deposit insurance scheme would further reduce the risk of bank runs in the euro area. #SoU2018 6/

Mario Draghi: We need an additional fiscal instrument to maintain economic convergence during crises and to avoid overburdening monetary policy. Its aim would be to provide an extra layer of stabilisation, thereby reinforcing confidence in national policies. #SoU2018 5/

Mario Draghi: Deepening private risk-sharing in the euro area would be beneficial for macroeconomic stability. But it does not happen by itself. Rather, it has to be enabled by public sector policies at national and EU level. #SoU2018 4/
Mario Draghi: The dichotomy between risk-sharing and risk-reduction is, in many ways, artificial. With the right policy framework, these two goals are mutually reinforcing. #SoU2018 3/

Mario Draghi: We need a fiscal backstop to European banking resolution. This will create confidence that resolution can always be enacted efficiently. The aim is not to bail banks out – borrowed funds are repaid by the private sector. #SoU2018 2/
President Mario Draghi is speaking today at the 2018 State of the Union conference at the @EuropeanUni in Florence. Watch live from 15:15 CET #SoU2018 https://t.co/sNDhWwlrSj

The tariffs recently announced by the US affect only a small portion of US trade or world trade. Their impact is likely to be modest. But a significant escalation of trade tensions would risk derailing the ongoing recovery in global trade and activity. 6/6

Between 2012 and 2016 world imports expanded at an average pace of 3% per year – less than half the average of the previous two decades. However, over the past one and a half years global trade has staged a cyclical revival. 5/6

The overall pace of trade liberalisation has slowed in recent years while the number of new discriminatory actions announced by G20 economies has increased steadily since 2012. 4/6 https://t.co/0IsWzmTcEC

This led to a sharp and widespread fall in applied tariff rates among both advanced and emerging economies. In turn, increasing trade openness contributed to the increase in global living standards. 3/6 https://t.co/TqVEA8AJ3d

The period prior to the financial crisis was characterised by a sharp increase in trade liberalisation. In the period between 1990 and 2010 more than 500 new preferential agreements were signed. 2/6 https://t.co/X0Fg7nOD0b

(THREAD) The risk of rising trade tensions has increased in recent weeks. What does this mean for the global economy? Read this thread summarising our latest Economic Bulletin box on the subject. [Full article: https://t.co/z2AtkF1nsP] 1/6 https://t.co/sl4uTNPB7E
